title: 104_s1869
content: The Act may be cited as the "Indian Health Care Improvement Technical Corrections Act of 1996" and references in the Act shall be considered to be made to the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. Technical corrections are made in the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. The Indian Health Care Improvement Technical Corrections Act of 1996 makes amendments to the definition of health professions and Indian Health Professions Scholarships. The amendments include adding "allopathic medicine" to the definition and expanding the scope of allied health professions. Additionally, changes are made to the active duty service obligation for recipients of Indian Health Professions Scholarships. The Indian Health Care Improvement Technical Corrections Act of 1996 amends the definition of health professions and Indian Health Professions Scholarships. It includes adding "allopathic medicine" and expanding allied health professions. Changes are made to the active duty service obligation for scholarship recipients, including service in an academic setting for recruitment and training of Indian health professionals. The Indian Health Care Improvement Technical Corrections Act of 1996 expands health professions scholarships to include allopathic medicine and allied health professions. It amends the active duty service obligation for scholarship recipients, allowing deferment for completion of required clinical training. The Indian Health Care Improvement Technical Corrections Act of 1996 expands health professions scholarships to include allopathic medicine and allied health professions. It amends the active duty service obligation for scholarship recipients, allowing deferment for completion of required clinical training. The active duty service obligation for individuals in the health profession will commence within 90 days after completing advanced clinical training. The Indian Health Care Improvement Technical Corrections Act of 1996 expands health professions scholarships to include allopathic medicine and allied health professions. It also amends the active duty service obligation for scholarship recipients, allowing deferment for completion of required clinical training. The active duty service obligation for individuals in the health profession will commence within 90 days after completing advanced clinical training. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act include changes in service requirements specified in subparagraphs and redesignation of subparagraphs. The Indian Health Care Improvement Technical Corrections Act of 1996 expands health professions scholarships to include allopathic medicine and allied health professions. It amends the active duty service obligation for scholarship recipients, allowing deferment for completion of required clinical training. The period of obligated service for Indian Health Scholarship recipients is detailed, including cancellation upon the recipient's death and provisions for waiver or suspension of obligations if deemed impossible to fulfill. The Secretary may waive the obligation for payment in cases of extreme hardship or good cause shown. For recipients of an Indian Health Scholarship, payment obligations cannot be discharged in bankruptcy unless five years have passed since the initial due date and the bankruptcy court approves. The bankruptcy court can discharge payment obligations for extreme hardship or good cause shown, except for Indian Health Scholarship recipients where approval is needed after five years from the due date. Amendments to Section 206 include reimbursement for health service charges. Amendments to Section 206 allow for reimbursement of health service charges by inserting "for such charges" and updating various subsections to clarify rights to recovery and damages. Amendments to Section 206 include changes such as inserting new paragraphs for intervention or separate civil action, updating subsections related to services covered under a self-insurance plan, and adding provisions for costs of action in enforcing the section. The amendments to Section 206 include the right of recovery for failure to provide reasonable assurances by fiduciaries of insurance companies or employee benefit plans. This allows the United States, Indian tribes, or tribal organizations to recover damages for hindering or preventing recovery under the section. Section 211(g) (25 U.S.C. 1621j(g)) is amended to update the years for the California Contract Health Services Demonstration Program. Section 405(c) (25 U.S.C. 1645(c)) is amended to adjust timelines for the Medicare and Medicaid Demonstration Program. Section 706(d) (25 U.S.C. 1665e(d)) is amended regarding the Gallup Alcohol and Substance Abuse Treatment Center. Section 706(d) (25 U.S.C. 1665e(d)) is amended to authorize appropriations for fiscal years 1996 through 2000 for subsection (b). Section 711(h) (25 U.S.C. 1665j(h)) and Section 821(i) (25 U.S.C. 1680k(i)) are also amended to update years for various demonstration programs.
